Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Carbon-Detected NMR Methods for the Study of Intrinsically Disordered Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this CAREER project is to develop new models for protein conformational dynamics that encompass not only well-folded proteins, but lead to the application of structural biological tools to highly flexible macromolecular systems without defined structures, such as intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs). A new NMR-based methodology will be implemented that utilizes carbon detected NMR to quantitatively characterize the properties of IDPs and the conformational transitions they often undergo upon binding other macromolecules. This research will yield new spectroscopic methods aimed at measuring conformational bias and dynamics in IDPs on the picoseconds-milliseconds timescales. The impact of the research protocol will be tested through studies of the microprocessor proteins DGCR8 and Drosha, which combine to affect the first step in the maturation of primary miRNA transcripts. Since its discovery ten years ago, miRNA has emerged as a major source of post-transcriptional gene regulation in multi-cellular organisms, but little is understood about the structural biology of the proteins involved in its biogenesis.

The integrated education objective of this CAREER project is to utilize NMR spectroscopy as a powerful example for middle and high school students of basic biological and chemical principles. The PI's partnerships with Penn State's Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day program, and the Higher Achievement Program, which brings students from disadvantaged backgrounds to Penn State for a summer emersion experience, will continue. To enable off-site outreach for communities across Pennsylvania, a portable demonstration laboratory is being built around a Terranova-MRI Earth's Field NMR system. This system is the size of two car batteries, weighs less than 15 kg, and is controlled by a standard laptop computer. Utilizing the natural magnetic field of the earth for educational NMR spectroscopy allows the PI to bring an informal education program to nearby rural school districts or underserved urban centers including Harrisburg and Reading. There the PI will provide hands on demonstrations of magnetic resonance at the interface of biology and chemistry to middle and high school students. Demonstrations with the Terranova will be supported by demonstrations of fundamental concepts such as Faraday induction and the phenomenon of resonance. Demonstration materials used for these events will be made available to members of the Nittany Chemical Society for independent use in order to broaden the impact of these educational activities. In addition, the Terranova system will be used for in-class demonstrations at both the freshman chemistry and graduate biophysics levels in order to further strengthen the association between real world magnetic resonance and classroom content. The ultimate goal of the educational component is to pique student's interest in biological chemistry in an effort to increase enrollment of top students in college and graduate education in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

In this CAREER research project the PI and supported trainees developed broad new experimental techniques in the area of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to describe the structure of highly flexible proteins, which have helped us to provide predictive insight into their function. The PI’s new experimental protocols and models, which connect molecular structure and function for highly flexible proteins, will lead in the future to the routine quantitative characterization of these molecular systems. This will help to eliminate the current systematic underrepresentation of highly flexible proteins in all structural databases (such as the protein data bank). While pursuing this research project, the PI and supported trainees applied the new methods developed to study the interaction between two proteins named FCP1 and Rap74. These molecules play a critical role in controlling the end-stages of the process whereby genetic information is decoded for a large fraction of the genes in the human genome. Prior to this project, it was difficult to understand how this interaction occurs and is controlled, because the high flexibility of FCP1 lead to the prediction that interaction with Rap74 should be very costly in terms of molecular energy, making it unclear how the vital interaction between these two proteins could occur when needed. As a result of this project, we now understand that the highly flexible protein FCP1 has a tendency to adopt certain structures more frequently than it should “by chance” and that this tendency prepares FCP1 for its interaction with Rap74. Therefore, our new methodology is already providing deep new insights into fundamental biology, with the potential to have broad impact on the fields of biochemistry and molecular genetics, as well as the biotechnology industry.

Broader Impacts

The integrated education objective of this CAREER project was to utilize the spectroscopic techniques essential for our laboratory’s research mission as a powerful example for middle and high school students of basic biological and chemical principles. During the course of this project, the PI and supported trainees interacted with several hundred students through four major points of contact. First, it has been our privilege to host approximately 40 students per year from the Higher Achievement Program for hands-on science demonstrations in our laboratory. Higher Achievement Scholars are from urban Washington D.C., are members of non-college (almost entirely minority) families, and are enrolled in an immersive program that prepares them to complete high school and pursue higher education. We work with them during their annual summer trip to Penn State. We have additionally had the opportunity to serve students from rural central Pennsylvania, both through Take our Daughters and Sons to Work Day and through individual school visits made to campus by area youth. Finally, we have participated in undergraduate research opportunities aimed at bringing non-Penn State undergraduate students from under-privileged backgrounds to campus for 10 week summer research programs. In addition to community engagement, this research program facilitated the Ph.D. training of several junior scientists and contributed directly to the completion of three Ph.D. degrees, with one additional current student anticipated to complete his training soon. Half of the supported trainees were from ethnic groups traditionally under-represented in science.
